Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Decide rules

X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

Steven A Rowe wrote:
> On 01/07/2010 at 7:17 PM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
>> Steven A Rowe wrote:
>>> I've been thinking of implementing BooleanDecideRule, extending
>>> PredicatedDecideRule to take an "operation" attribute
>>> (=AND/OR/NOT), accepting nested PredicatedDecideRule's.
>> That sounds useful, though since the ACCEPT/REJECT/PASS logic isn't
>> quite boolean, you might want to describe the combiners in other terms.
>>
>> For example, if you had an "OR" rule, and its three internal rules
>> return {ACCEPT, REJECT, PASS}, what is the desired result? (Is ACCEPT
>> like 'true' or REJECT like 'true'? I think depends on whether you're
>> ruling things in or out at that point.)
> 
> My thought process was as follows:
> 
> 1. Decide rules have two functions: first, rule in/out (a.k.a. match),
>    where rule out=PASS (=NONE in H3, right?); and second, decide
>    - REJECT/ACCEPT.

Generally, yes. But I'd usually only say "rule in/out" for the final 
decision ruling a URI into the crawl or out of the crawl. Also, although 
most of the existing rules are (a) applied on the basis of a test; and 
(b) "one-way", if the test succeed, one decision is applied, but express 
no opinion if the test fails -- this test-and-one-decision approach is 
not required of all rules. A single rule could give all of ACCEPT, 
REJECT, and NONE decisions.

> 2. Rules contained in a boolean rule would be queried solely for their
>    match function - whether they rule a URI in or out.
> 3. Boolean rule containers could supply the REJECT/ACCEPT decision for
>    all contained rules based on a poll of these rules' match function:
> 
>    - operation=OR: return configured boolean-container decision if any
>      contained rule matches (rules in); otherwise, return NONE (PASS).
> 
>    - operation=AND: return configured boolean-container decision if
>      all contained rules match (rule in); otherwise, return NONE (PASS).
> 
> I think my #2 idea above has two problems: a) matching and deciding
> are not separate functions on decide rules as currently implemented
> - this could likely be addressed through refactoring, though; and 
> b) this proposal would cause configured decisions on rules 
> in a boolean container to be ignored.  I don't know how to address
> the latter problem, which may be a fatal flaw.

I think the risk here is that AND and OR have well-defined meanings in 
boolean logic, but since ACCEPT and REJECT are not the same as 'true' 
and 'false', and there's the added layer of 'apply the configured 
decision', the meanings brought in from boolean logic are just as likely 
to confuse as clarify. Hence, my preference for wordy descriptions like 
"IfAllAccept"/"IfAllReject" rather than "AND".

- Gordon @ IA

>> We've consciously gone in the direction of *more* rules, descriptively
>> named, rather than fewer rules with internal settings (except with
>> regard to the applied decision). So we have 'MatchesRegexDecideRule' and
>> 'NotMatchesRegexDecideRule', rather than a single 'RegexDecideRule'
>> which either has a 'not' toggle or has to be wrapped in a 'not'.
>>
>> Thinking of 'AND'- and 'OR'-like situations, this would suggest
>> composite rules like 'IfAllAcceptDecideRule'/'IfAllRejectDecideRule',
>> and 'IfAnyAcceptDecideRule'/'IfAnyRejectDecideRule'.
>>
>> Again, this may seem a little strange but is based on experience where
>> deep boolean combinations caused difficulty keeping track of whether, at
>> a certain nesting, 'true' or 'false' implied 'in', 'out', or 'no
>> opinion'.
> 
> Thanks for the info, I'll think more about this.
> 
> Steve
>
